questions.text: A patient with chronic liver failure presented with acute variceal bleeding. The BP was 80/60 mm Hg. Which of the following is not done?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Platelet transfusion Treatment of acute variceal bleeding involves careful volume resuscitation, administration of antibiotics, drugs to reduce portal hypertension, and prompt endoscopy therapy. A combination of pharmacologic and endoscopy therapy is employed to prevent variceal bleeding.

Highyeild:

Platelet transfusion is not done in case of active variceal. Management of variceal bleeding: Blood transfusion Correction of coagulopathy Endoscopic sclerotherapy on its analogs Drug therapy – vasopressin on its analogs Somatostatin analogs like octreotide Balloon tamponade Transjugular Intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) Surgery – Portosystemic shunts, splenectomy & gastric devascularization.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, B & C : Octreotide infusion, Endoscopy banding, and TIPS are the primary management protocols for variceal bleeding.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the Image.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Monopolar cautery Electrosurgery uses high-frequency electrical current to cut, coagulate, desiccate, and manufacture tissue. It can be performed using either monopolar or bipolar energy in conjunction with a specialized instrument. The difference between these two methods is that with monopolar electrosurgery, the current passes from the probe electrode to the tissue and through the patient to a return pad to complete the electric current circuit. In bipolar electrosurgery, the current only passes through the tissue between the two arms of the forceps-shaped electrode.

questions.text: In a child with acute scrotal pain and swelling where testicular torsion is highly suspected, how would you proceed:

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate scrotal exploration only on the side of swelling

options.label: B
options.text: Immediate scrotal exploration on the same side and delayed exploration on the other side

options.label: C
options.text: Immediate scrotal exploration on both sides

questions.correct_answer: C. Immediate scrotal exploration on both sides
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Immediate scrotal exploration on both sides In a case of suspected testicular torsion, immediate investigation needs to be done on both the symptomatic and the asymptomatic sides. In the case of Testicular torsion, the blood supply to the testicle is compromised due to the twisting of the spermatic cord within the tunica vaginalis, resulting in Ischemia to the epididymis and the testis.

Highyeild:

Testicular torsion is the twisting of the spermatic cord and its contents such that the testicular blood supply becomes compromised Incidence : 10–15% of acute scrotal diseases in children Pathophysiology : High Investment in the tunica vaginalis Inversion of the testis Separation of the epididymis from the body of the testis Factors determining damage to the testis The extent of the twist Duration of the episode Clinical Features : The joint is between 10 and 25 years Sudden severe pain in the groin and lower abdomen Nauseated and Vomit Scrotum - swollen and tender, while the skin is usually not erythematous initially Testis - swollen and tender and seems high within the scrotum Cremasteric Reflex - Lost Differential Diagnosis : Epididymo - Orchitis Idiopathic Scrotal Oedema Management : White doppler Ultrasound Scanning (Confirms the absence of blood supply) Urgent Scrotal Exploration

questions.text: What is the mechanism by which the following technique works?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Negative pressure The principle behind this wound healing procedure, as shown in the Image, is negative pressure wound therapy. Applying intermittent negative pressure of approximately - 125 mmHg hastens debridement and granulation tissue formation in chronic wounds and ulcers. This type of wound healing is known as Vacuum Assisted closure dressing {VAC}

Highyeild:

Negative-pressure wound therapy (e.g., vacuum-assisted closure; VAC®) uses intermittent or continuous topical negative pressure (up to –125 mmHg) through a sealed foam dressing to stimulate granulation tissue formation, reduce local edema and tissue exudate and reduce bacterial load. negative-pressure wound therapy (NPWT) is now widely used. It is not a replacement for definitive wound closure but is a valuable adjunct. Negative pressure helps draw the wound edges together, remove exudate, reduce edema, and promote granulation tissue formation. NPWT is not recommended in the setting of exposed vessels, malignancy, untreated osteomyelitis, necrotic tissue, or non-enteric and unexplored fistulae The technique has numerous applications, including dressing to secure a skin graft to its recipient bed, temporary coverage of a complex acute wound until definitive cover, or managing chronic wounds such as pressure ulcers.

Extraedge:

Reconstruction options for wound closure Primary closure Secondary closure Tertiary (delayed primary) closure NPWT Split-thickness skin graft Full-thickness skin graft Dermal matrices Local, regional, or pedicled flap Tissue expansion Free flap

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in massive blood transfusion:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Metabolic alkalosis Massive blood transfusion results in mild metabolic Alkalosis as the citrate in the transfused blood is converted to BICARBONATE. Metabolic alkalosis is more likely to develop in renal insufficiency. Metabolic alkalosis is most significantly seen in massive Blood transfusions leading to further systemic complications.

Highyeild:

BLOOD TRANSFUSION: Indications: Acute blood loss, to replace circulating volume and maintain oxygen delivery Perioperative anemia, to ensure adequate oxygen delivery during the perioperative phase Symptomatic chronic anemia without hemorrhage or impending surgery. Complications from a single transfusion Incompatibility hemolytic transfusion reaction Febrile transfusion reaction Allergic reaction Infection: Bacterial infection (usually due to faulty storage); hepatitis; HIV; Malaria; Air embolism Thrombophlebitis Transfusion­ related to acute lung injury (usually from FFP). Complications from massive transfusion include: Coagulopathy, Hypocalcaemia Hyperkalaemia Hypokalaemia Hypothermia.

questions.text: Arrange the following types of renal injury in order from lower to higher grade: Subcapsular perirenal hematoma Hematomas confined Gerota’s fascia Avulsion of the pedicle Shattered kidney Select the correct answer using the code below:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1 → 2 → 4 → 3

Highyeild:

Renal Trauma: Kidneys are retroperitoneal structures; they are relatively fixed by their vascular pedicles and are well protected by perinephric fat, posterior solid abdominal wall muscles, and the lower rib cage. Renal trauma is usually a part of polytrauma and is present in only 5% of all trauma cases. Mechanism Of Injury: Trauma may be penetrating or blunt, the latter being far more common Common Modes: Head-on collisions in road traffic accidents Falls from height Contact sports Sudden rapid deceleration (Avulsion Injury to ureter at PUJ) Penetrating injuries cause direct tissue disruption and are usually associated with adjacent organ injuries Presentation: Loss of Consciousness Hemodynamic Shock Haematuria (Pathognomic) Abdominal Pain with flank contusions Diagnosis: CECT of the abdomen is necessary to delineate the type and extent of renal injury. It provides information about the presence of parenchymal laceration, its depth, extension into the pelvicalyceal system, and the extent of urinary extravasation. It also provides valuable information about other abdominal injuries and the status of the contralateral kidney. Common indications for CECT in abdominal trauma include: Abdominal trauma with gross haematuria Microscopic haematuria with hypotension (systolic <90 mmHg) Rapid deceleration injury Children with microscopic haematuria (>5 red blood cells [RBCs]) All penetrating injuries. Indications for emergency surgical exploration are: Expanding or pulsatile retroperitoneal hematoma PUJ avulsion Renal pedicle injury hemodynamic instability Treatment: Conservative management with close surveillance is sufficient in the majority of cases of isolated renal trauma. Lower-grade injuries, sometimes including grade IV, can be managed conservatively with bed rest, antibiotics in case of penetrating injuries, and serial hemoglobin estimation. Reimaging is usually done after 2–4 days in cases of falling hemoglobin levels, fever, or expanding fank mass. An internal DJ stent or PCN can manage a persistent urinary leak.

Extraedge:

Effect of raised intra-abdominal pressure on individual organ function. System Effect Renal Increase in renal vascular resistance leading to a reduction in glomerular filtration rate and impaired renal function Cardiovascular Decrease in venous return resulting in decreased cardiac output because of both a reduction in preload and an increase in afterload Respiratory Increased ventilation pressures because of splinting of the diaphragm, decreased lung compliance and increased airway pressures Visceral effects Reduction in visceral perfusion Intracranial effects Severe rises in intracranial pressures

questions.text: Identify the grade of the bed score shown in the image given below.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Grade-4 In the above-given image of a pressure sore, there is a total thickness loss seen with an exposure of the bone site. Hence it can be classified as a Grade 4 pressure sore. Pressure ulcers can be graded according to an internationally recognized grading system based on the extent of skin loss. Category 1 ulcers involve non-blanching erythema with intact skin. Category 2 ulcers have partial thickness skin loss and appear as shallow open ulcers with a red-pink wound bed or an intact or ruptured serum-filled blister. Category 3 ulcers have full-thickness skin loss, with subcutaneous fat visible in the wound but not bone, tendon, or muscle. Category 4 ulcers have complete thickness loss with exposed bone, tendon, or muscle; osteomyelitis may develop at these sites.

Highyeild:

Pressure Sores Patients undergoing surgery for a prolonged period are vulnerable to developing a pressure sore or worsening a pre-existing sore due to prolonged immobility during, and sometimes after, the operation. Careful positioning and padding of the patient are standard practices intraoperatively to reduce the risk. Pressure sores occur due to friction or persisting pressure on soft tissues. They mainly affect the pressure points of a recumbent patient, including the sacrum, greater trochanter, and heels. Poor nutritional status, dehydration, lack of mobility, and nerve-block anesthesia technique are risk factors . Common sites for pressure injuries and ulcers Ischium Greater trochanter Sacrum Heel Malleolus Occiput Management : Early mobilization of the patient and regular inspection of pressure points by the nursing Team can act to prevent pressure sores. High-risk patients may be nursed on an air mattress , which automatically relieves the pressure areas. Surgical Management : Primary closure and skin grafting should be avoided as they are likely to fail. In suitable patients, successful reconstruction options include the use of large fasciocutaneous or musculocutaneous flaps . If possible, use a fap that can be advanced further if there is recurrence and does not interfere with the planning of neighboring faps that may be used.

Extraedge:

In chronic wounds, such as in pressure sores, burns or osteomyelitis, the chronicity of the inflammatory environment can lead to the development of a Marjolin ulcer. This is a rare but aggressive form of squamous cell carcinoma with a high propensity for distant metastasis. A low index of suspicion must be observed in chronic wounds that undergo sudden phenotypic change, so early biopsy is advocated.

questions.text: Identify the drain shown in the Image?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Jackson Pratt drain A Jackson-Pratt drain ( JP drain) is a closed-suction medical device commonly used as a post-operative drain for collecting bodily fluids from surgical sites. The device consists of an internal drain connected to a grenade-shaped bulb via plastic tubing.

Highyeild:

Drains: Drains allow fluid that might collect in a body cavity to drain freely to the surface. The fluid to be drained may include blood, serum, pus, urine, feces, bile, lymph, or air Classification: Open Drain(Passive drainage) Closed Drains Suctioned Drains(Active Drainage) Non-Suction Drains (Passive Drainage) Nasogastric Drainage: There is no doubt that selective use of nasogastric tubes has an important place in the perioperative management of patients However, there is a trend to move away from routine placement of nasogastric tubes and from keeping them in place for long lengths of time when inserted. T-tube Drains: A T-tube may be inserted after exploration of the common bile duct and stone retrieval or following repair of a damaged common bile duct . The principle is to allow bile drain while the sphincter of Oddi is in spasm postoperatively and to act as a safety valve if there are any stones retained in the distal ordinary bile duct

Extraedge:

Barbed sutures are increasingly being used for fascial closure. This suture has tiny barbs in a spiral arrangement that allow an even distribution of tension across the incision rather than just at the knots Barbed sutures have also been shown to have a similar hernia recurrence rate in fascial plication for rectus diastasis . They are secured without knots, thus allowing for faster placement, and eliminate the knot as a nidus for infection

questions.text: Identify the procedure below: (Video Based Question)
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lahey's method Lahey method of palpating the posterior surface of the thyroid gland The video demonstrates Lahey's method of thyroid palpation, which involves pushing the lobes of the thyroid to one side for palpation. To palpate the left lobe, the examiner uses their left hand to push the lobe laterally and palpates it with the right hand. Examiner stands in front of the patient Gland is pushed to one side, ideal for palpating margins

Highyeild:

Differential diagnosis of hyperthyroidism INCREASED HORMONE SYNTHESIS (INCREASED RAIU) RELEASE OF PREFORMED HORMONE (DECREASED RAIU) Graves' disease (diffuse toxic goiter) Toxic multinodular goiter Toxic adenoma Drug induced—amiodarone, iodine Thyroid cancer Struma ovarii Hydatidiform mole TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma Thyroiditis—acute phase of Hashimoto's thyroiditis, subacute thyroiditis Factitious (iatrogenic) thyrotoxicosis "Hamburger thyrotoxicosis” RAIU = radioactive iodine uptake; TSH = thyroid-stimulating hormone.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B: Describes Pemberton's sign , which is not a method but a test based on the principle that obstruction to significant veins in the thorax can cause engorgement of neck veins. Patients are asked to raise their hands above their heads and touch their ears with their arms. Development of facial congestion and breathlessness indicates a positive sign and is seen in patients with retrosternal goiter. Option C: Kocher's method demonstrates the pressure effect of the thyroid gland on the trachea or larynx. Lateral compression of the gland can result in stridor. Option D: Crile method: Thumb on the gland, the patient is asked to swallow (To look for nodularity or slight thyroid enlargement).
